items.label: thm-parabolic-harnack
items.title: Parabolic Harnack Inequality for Kinetic Operators
items.content:
135: :label: thm-parabolic-harnack
136: 
137: **References**:
138: - Kusuoka & Stroock (1985, *J. Fac. Sci. Univ. Tokyo Sect. IA Math.* 32:1-76)
139: - Hérau & Nier (2004, *Comm. Math. Phys.* 253:741-754)
140: 
141: Let $u(t, z)$ be a non-negative solution to the kinetic Fokker-Planck equation:
142: 
143: $$
144: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}^* u + h(t, z)
145: 
146: $$
147: 
148: on a cylinder $Q_R = [t_0, t_0 + R^2] \times B_R(z_0) \subset [0, \infty) \times \Omega$, where $h$ is a bounded source term with $\|h\|_\infty \leq C_h$.
149: 
150: Then there exist constants $C_H$ and $\alpha > 0$ (depending on $\gamma, \sigma_v, \|F\|_{\text{Lip}}, d$) such that:
151: 
152: $$
153: \sup_{Q_{R/2}^-} u \leq C_H \left( \inf_{Q_{R/2}^+} u + R^2 C_h \right)
154: 
155: $$
156: 
157: where:
158: - $Q_{R/2}^- = [t_0, t_0 + R^2/4] \times B_{R/2}(z_0)$ (early time, smaller ball)
159: - $Q_{R/2}^+ = [t_0 + 3R^2/4, t_0 + R^2] \times B_{R/2}(z_0)$ (late time, smaller ball)
160: 
161: **Interpretation**: The supremum over early times is controlled by the infimum over late times, shifted by a time lag. This is the hypoelliptic "smoothing" property.
162: 
163: **Proof Sketch**: The proof uses sub-Riemannian geometry and the Carnot-Carathéodory distance $d_{\text{cc}}$ induced by the Hörmander vector fields. The key steps are:
164: 
165: 1. Construct a Lyapunov function adapted to the hypoelliptic structure
166: 2. Apply maximum principle arguments in time-space cylinders
167: 3. Use the bracket condition to propagate information from velocity to position variables
168: 4. Iterate the estimates to obtain the final bound
items.section: ## 2. Hypoelliptic Regularity and Parabolic Harnack Inequalities
items.raw_directive:
132: The key technical tool for establishing $L^\infty$ bounds is the **parabolic Harnack inequality** for hypoelliptic operators. This inequality provides quantitative control of the supremum of a solution in terms of its infimum over a shifted time-space cylinder.
133: 
134: :::{prf:theorem} Parabolic Harnack Inequality for Kinetic Operators
135: :label: thm-parabolic-harnack
136: 
137: **References**:
138: - Kusuoka & Stroock (1985, *J. Fac. Sci. Univ. Tokyo Sect. IA Math.* 32:1-76)
139: - Hérau & Nier (2004, *Comm. Math. Phys.* 253:741-754)
140: 
141: Let $u(t, z)$ be a non-negative solution to the kinetic Fokker-Planck equation:
142: 
143: $$
144: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}^* u + h(t, z)
145: 
146: $$
147: 
148: on a cylinder $Q_R = [t_0, t_0 + R^2] \times B_R(z_0) \subset [0, \infty) \times \Omega$, where $h$ is a bounded source term with $\|h\|_\infty \leq C_h$.
149: 
150: Then there exist constants $C_H$ and $\alpha > 0$ (depending on $\gamma, \sigma_v, \|F\|_{\text{Lip}}, d$) such that:
151: 
152: $$
153: \sup_{Q_{R/2}^-} u \leq C_H \left( \inf_{Q_{R/2}^+} u + R^2 C_h \right)
154: 
155: $$
156: 
157: where:
158: - $Q_{R/2}^- = [t_0, t_0 + R^2/4] \times B_{R/2}(z_0)$ (early time, smaller ball)
159: - $Q_{R/2}^+ = [t_0 + 3R^2/4, t_0 + R^2] \times B_{R/2}(z_0)$ (late time, smaller ball)
160: 
161: **Interpretation**: The supremum over early times is controlled by the infimum over late times, shifted by a time lag. This is the hypoelliptic "smoothing" property.
162: 
163: **Proof Sketch**: The proof uses sub-Riemannian geometry and the Carnot-Carathéodory distance $d_{\text{cc}}$ induced by the Hörmander vector fields. The key steps are:
164: 
165: 1. Construct a Lyapunov function adapted to the hypoelliptic structure
166: 2. Apply maximum principle arguments in time-space cylinders
167: 3. Use the bracket condition to propagate information from velocity to position variables
168: 4. Iterate the estimates to obtain the final bound

items.label: thm-exponential-survival
items.title: Exponential Survival Time (QSD Theory)
items.content:
625: :label: thm-exponential-survival
626: 
627: **References**:
628: - Champagnat & Villemonais (2016, *Ann. Appl. Probab.* 26:3547-3569)
629: - `06_convergence.md` Theorem 4.5 (lines 906-947)
630: 
631: For the Euclidean Gas initialized from the quasi-stationary distribution $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$, the absorption time $\tau_\dagger$ (first time when all walkers are dead) satisfies:
632: 
633: $$
634: \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[\tau_\dagger] = e^{\Theta(N)}
635: 
636: $$
637: 
638: Moreover, for any finite time horizon $T > 0$ independent of $N$:
639: 
640: $$
641: \mathbb{P}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}(\tau_\dagger > T) \geq 1 - T e^{-\Theta(N)}
642: 
643: $$
644: 
645: **Interpretation**: The probability of survival up to time $T$ approaches 1 exponentially fast in $N$. Total extinction is exponentially rare for large swarms.
646: 
647: **Proof Sketch**: The key mechanism is the **revival operator**. From `07_mean_field.md`, dead walkers are revived by cloning from the alive population. The revival rate is proportional to the alive mass:
648: 
649: $$
650: \frac{dm_a}{dt} \geq -C_{\text{death}} m_a + C_{\text{revival}} m_d = -C_{\text{death}} m_a + C_{\text{revival}}(1 - m_a)
651: 
652: $$
653: 
654: where $C_{\text{death}}, C_{\text{revival}} > 0$ are the death and revival rates.
655: 
656: At equilibrium ($dm_a/dt = 0$):
657: 
658: $$
659: m_a^* = \frac{C_{\text{revival}}}{C_{\text{death}} + C_{\text{revival}}} > 0
660: 
661: $$
662: 
663: The variance $\text{Var}(k_t)$ scales as $O(N)$ (standard fluctuation scaling), so:
664: 
665: $$
666: \mathbb{P}(k_t = 0) \approx \mathbb{P}\left( |k_t - k_*| > k_* \right) \leq \frac{\text{Var}(k_t)}{k_*^2} = O(N / N^2) = O(1/N)
667: 
668: $$

items.label: thm-bounded-density-ratio-main
items.title: Bounded Density Ratio for the Euclidean Gas (RIGOROUS)
items.content:
920: :label: thm-bounded-density-ratio-main
921: 
922: **Status**: Complete rigorous proof
923: 
924: **Assumptions**:
925: - Euclidean Gas dynamics with parameters $(\gamma, \sigma_v, \sigma_x, U, R)$ from `02_euclidean_gas.md`
926: - Cloning position jitter $\sigma_x > 0$ (`03_cloning.md` line 6022)
927: - Initial density $\|f_0\|_\infty \leq M_0 < \infty$
928: - Number of walkers $N \geq N_0$ sufficiently large
929: 
930: Then there exists a finite constant $M = M(\gamma, \sigma_v, \sigma_x, U, R, M_0, N) < \infty$ such that:
931: 
932: $$
933: \sup_{t \geq 0} \sup_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}} \frac{d\tilde{\mu}_t}{d\tilde{\pi}_{\text{QSD}}}(x) \leq M
934: 
935: $$
936: 
937: where $\tilde{\mu}_t = \mu_t / \|\mu_t\|$ is the normalized empirical measure and $\tilde{\pi}_{\text{QSD}}$ is the normalized quasi-stationary distribution.
938: 
939: **Explicit Formula**:
940: 
941: $$
942: M = \max(M_1, M_2) < \infty
943: 
944: $$
945: 
946: where:
947: - $M_1 = \dfrac{C_{\text{hypo}}(M_0, T_0, \gamma, \sigma_v, \sigma_x, U, R)}{c_{\sigma_x, R} \cdot c_{\text{mass}}}$ is the **early-time bound** (Regime 1)
948: - $M_2 = \dfrac{C_{\text{late}}^{\text{total}}}{c_{\sigma_x, R} \cdot c_{\text{mass}}}$ is the **late-time bound** (Regime 2)
949: 
950: **Component constants**:
951: - $C_{\text{hypo}}$ is the hypoelliptic smoothing constant (Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-linfty-full-operator`)
952: - $C_{\text{late}}^{\text{total}} = C_\pi + C_{\text{late}}$ where $C_{\text{late}}$ is from the Nash-Aronson estimate (Lemmas {prf:ref}`lem-linearization-qsd`, {prf:ref}`lem-l1-to-linfty-near-qsd`)
953: - $c_{\sigma_x, R} = (2\pi\sigma_x^2)^{-d/2} \exp(-(2R)^2 / (2\sigma_x^2))$ (Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-gaussian-kernel-lower-bound`)
954: - $c_{\text{mass}} = \min\!\left(c_{\text{early}}, \frac{m_{\text{eq}}}{2}\right)$ (Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-mass-lower-bound-high-prob`)
955: - $T_0 = O(\kappa_{\text{QSD}}^{-1})$ is the equilibration time
956: 
957: **Key Property**: Both $M_1$ and $M_2$ are finite and time-independent, yielding a uniform bound for all $t \geq 0$.
958: 
959: **Probability Statement**:
960: - **Finite horizon**: For any fixed $T < \infty$, the bound holds with probability $\geq 1 - CT e^{-\delta N}$ for all $t \in [0, T]$.
961: - **Infinite horizon (asymptotic)**: The bound holds **deterministically for all $t \geq 0$** on the survival event $\{\tau_\dagger = \infty\}$ (see Section 4.4).

items.label: thm-hk-convergence-conditional
items.title: Exponential HK-Convergence of the Fragile Gas (CONDITIONAL ON SURVIVAL)
items.content:
1852: :label: thm-hk-convergence-conditional
1853: 
1854: Under the foundational axioms of the Euclidean Gas (`01_fragile_gas_framework.md`, `02_euclidean_gas.md`, `03_cloning.md`), the empirical measure $\mu_t$ converges exponentially to the quasi-stationary distribution $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ in the Hellinger-Kantorovich metric:
1855: 
1856: $$
1857: \text{HK}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) \leq C_{\text{HK}} e^{-\kappa_{\text{HK}} t}
1858: 
1859: $$
1860: 
1861: with explicit rate $\kappa_{\text{HK}} = \kappa_{\text{HK}}(\gamma, \sigma_v, \sigma_x, U, R, N) > 0$.
1862: 
1863: **Status**: CONDITIONAL ON SURVIVAL (standard in QSD theory)
1864: 
1865: **Scope**:
1866: 1. **Finite horizon**: For any $T < \infty$, the HK convergence bound holds with probability $\geq 1 - CT e^{-\delta N}$ for all $t \in [0, T]$
1867: 2. **Infinite horizon**: On the survival event $\{\tau_\dagger = \infty\}$, the HK convergence bound holds deterministically for all $t \geq 0$
